translatedText: yeh ek bohot acchi puzzle hai

input: Suppose you randomly orient a cube in three-dimensional space, and you look at the area of its shadow.
translatedText: Suppose ki aapne ek cube to randomly space me feinka aur uski parchai ke area ko dekhaà¥¤

input: What's the expected value for that area?
translatedText: toh us area ki expected value kya hogi?

input: Or phrased another way, if you repeat this process over and over, randomly tossing that cube and tallying up the areas that you find, what would the empirically measured mean of all those measured areas approach as you do this more and more?
translatedText: Ya dusre shabdo mein, agar aap iss process bar bar repeat karenge, uss cube ko randomly feink ke uske shadow ke areas ko add kar ke unka avarage nikale toh wo avarage konsi value ko approach karega jab aap bohot saare areas ka avarage nikaloge?

input: Strictly speaking, in referencing the shadow, that would depend on where the light source is, but here we're doing the typical mathematician thing of thinking of the light source as being infinitely far away, so the shadow is just a flat projection, say, onto the xy-plane.
translatedText: agar dekha jaye toh asli zindagi mein parchai ka shape iss baat par depend karega ki light source kaha hai, but yaha hum log ek typical mathematician ki tarah assume kar rahe hai ki light source infinitly dur hai to parchai bas ek x-y plane par flat projection ki tarah hai

input: It is definitely a hard problem, and I'm curious actually to hear how you would approach it in the comments.
translatedText: Yeh is bohot mushki problem hai, aur mai comment section mein jaanna chahunga ki aap log isse kaise approach karoge?

input: The longest video I've made to date explores this question.
translatedText: Meri aaj tak ki sabsi lambi video iss question ko explore karti hai

input: Really, it's a saga about two distinct problem-solving styles, and why popularizations of math tend to have a bias in what kinds of styles they represent.
translatedText: Asal mein, yeh 2 alag problem-solving styles ke baare mein hai, aur math ke popularisation me ek bias kyu hota hai jin styles ko wo represent karte hai unme

input: The shadow puzzle just turns out to be a very perfect setting for that story.
translatedText: yeh puzzle bas uss story ko batane ke liye perfect hai.
